title: A Compact Excimer Lamp Constructed by Piezoelectric Transformer

authors.name: Kenji Teranishi
affiliations: Japan Society for the Promotion of Science

abstract: A compact excimer lamp constructed with a piezoelectric transformer (PT) has been developed in our laboratory. This excimer lamp is designed based on the excitation of a dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) in a He-Xe mixture generated by the PT, which is driven with low applied voltages of several tens of volts (15-45V). Vacuum ultraviolet (VUV) radiated from the lamp is detected by a phototube having a spectral response region ranging from 160 to 320 nm in conjunction with an optical filter to discriminate the VUV and UV regions. The VUV radiation in the wavelength range 160-200 nm is recognized in this experiment. This may be derived from the 172-nm light emission by the transitions of the Xe2 excimers to the ground state. Investigations into the radiated VUV intensity are carried out by varying the gas pressure and the gap length. The optimal condition for the present excimer lamp is determined.
full_text:
J. Light & Vis. Env. Vol.3J, No.J, 2007 5 
Pa per 
A Compact Excimer Lamp Constructed by Piezoelectric Transformer 
Kenji TERANISHl* and Haruo ITOH** 
* Researdl Felbw of the Japan Soc~'ety for the Promotion of Scien~ (Chiba Institute of Technology) 
- Graduate Sibool of Engineering, Chiba Insti'tute of l~nology 
Received December 2, 2005, Accepted January 24, 2007 
ABSTRACT 
A compact excimer lamp eonstructed with a piezoelectric transforrner (PT) has been developed in our laboratory. 
This excimer lamp is designed based on the excitaton of a dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) in a He¥Xe mixture 
generated by the PT, which is driven with low applied voltages of several tens of volts (i5~5\/). Vacuum urtr:aviolet 
(VUV) radiated tom tfle lamp is detected by a phototube having a spectral response region ranging ftom i60 to 320 
nm in conjuncton with an optical filter to discriminate the VUV and UV regions. The VUV radiaton in the wavelength 
range 160-200 nm is recognized in this experiment. This may be derived 'rrom the 1 72-nm light emission by the 
transitons of the Xe2 excimers to the ground state. Investigatons into the radiated VUV intensity are carried out by 
varying the gas pressure and the gap length. The optimal condition for the present excimer lamp is determined. 
KEYWORDS: piezoelectric transformer, excimer lamp, dielectric bamer dlscharge He~Xe mlxture Xe 
atrnospherlc pressure 
excimer, 
1 . Intuduction 
Excimer lamps are equipment designed as light sources 
capable of radiating high intensity and narrow band uv 
light or vacuum ultraviolet (VUV) lightD ~ . To obtain 
excimer formation in the lamps in a simple mauner and 
with great efficiency, dielectric barrier discharges (DBDS) 
in noble gases or a noble gas/halogen mixture are widely 
utitize d, and availability of the light wavelength dep ends 
on the kind and composition of working molecules. It is 
comprehended that particularly xenon ex(imer lanrps, 
which provide more powerful VUV radiation at 172 nrn, is 
liable to destroy molecular bonds for ahnost all agents. For 
this reason, the lamps have been widely used for the 
purpose of industrial application, such as dry cleaning and 
photochemical vapor deposition in semiconductor 
processing, surface modification, and fabrication of oxide 
film3). In re~nt years, experimental studies and 
computational simulations have been actively perfouned 
on the characteristics of the xenon DBD tog:ether with 
geometry opttmization for electrodes and excitation 
regime for xenon excimer lamps with a view to obtaining 
higher intcnsity and achieving efflcient operation~)~lD. 
Vaiious types of plasma reactors incorporating 
piezoelectric transformers (PT) 12)¥19) have been developed 
in our laboratory. In these reactors, discharges are 
generated directly on the PT surface, inducing high 
voltage caused by the piezoelectric effect. Such plasma 
generation methods allow the design of compact plasma 
*Present a~liation: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, 
lchinoseki National College ofTechnology 
reactors to be accomplished because the PT plays roles of 
both a high voltage source and a discharge electrode. 
Previously, a PTbased ozone generator was proposed and 
the ozone generation characteristics were investigated by 
feeding the generator with oxygen and airl5). In the case of 
oxygen-fed ozone generation, ozone was obtained at a 
con~ntration of 3.1-20.3 g/Nm3 and maximurn ozone yield 
efiiciency to the extent of 223g/kWh was achievedl9). 
These values are competitive enough to be compared to 
the recently reported DBD-type ozone generators 
operated in room temperautcl9). 
An excimer lamp designed based on the PT has also 
been exaJnined to be entrusted to further investigation for 
application of the plasma reactor. This paper describes the 
experixnental investigations with a view to detecting VUV 
radiation emitted from the excimer lamp, using a 
phototube combined with an optional glass filter. 
Characteristics of the VUV radiation are also observed 
with respect to different types of gas pressure and gap 
lengths to determine the optirnal driving conditions for the 
ex(imer lamp . 
2. Experimental 
2.1 PTbased excixLer lamp 
A schematic diagram of the PTbased excimer lamp in 
configuration and drcuit is shown in Fig. 1(a) . The lamp 
contains a Rosen-type PT made of Pb(Zr, Ti)03 measuring 
60X13xl mm. A quartz glass plate includirrg mesh wires 
on its back is employed as the dielectric electrode having 
the metallic back electrode allowing the generated VUV to

(b) Discharge chamber and VUV detecting system 
Figure 1 Experlmenta] arrangement 
be passed to the outer side of the lanrp. The quartz glass 
has an 80"/, transmittance at 170 nm. As shown in the 
figure, the PT and dielectric layer together with the back 
electrode are fixed by a spacer to be supported at the node 
of the mechanical vibration of the PT. Provided that the 
PT is driven at (1/2)A-mode vibration, a high voltage is 
induced on the secondary part of the PT. This results in 
the DBD plasma generation in the gap space as shown in 
the figure . The ( 1/2)A-mode vibration is de alt with as 
condition, where a half wavelength of the mechanical 
vibration is equal to the length of the PT. However the 
vibration is subj ect to the primary voltage and discharge 
current to a ~rtain amount of extent. Therefore frequency 
of the prirnary voltage is adjusted arbitral:ily between 26.3 
and 26.6 kHz. The gap length is adjusted according to 
thickness of the spacer. A secondary voltage appearing at 
the tip of the PT is measured by an oscilloscope and 
potential divider. Thus discharge power is estinated by a 
Lissajous figure formed by the secondary voltage and 
voltage across the 2-nF capacitor counected between the 
back electrode and the ground. The experimental 
arrangement is illustrated in Fig. 1(b). The excimer larnp 
unit depicted in Fig. l(a) is placed in the chamber center. 
All electrical feedthroughs mounted on the chamber 
flanges. In advance of experixnents, the chamber is 
evacuated to the full extent reaching 10-5 Pa to be filled 
with a He-Xe (10.8"/o) mixture in a range from 400 Torr 
(53.3 kP~ to 1000 Torr (133.3 kPa). The radiated VUV is 
detected using a phototube, whereas the output phototube 
voltage is recorded using an oscilloscope connected 
through a detector drcuit. 
2.2 VUV detection method 
Full expectation is made in this study that the VUV at 
172 nm will be radiated from the Xe2* excimers in the He-

Xe DBD. The cathode radiant sensitivity of the phototube 
~)Q~) is shown in Fig. 2. The phototube responds to 160-
320-nm wavelength light, where both VUV and uv 
regions are included. Hence, an optional filter (uv-250), 
which is adopted to dis(ximinate the VUV and uv regions, 
is placed between the lamp and the phototube. 
The spectral transmittance of the uv-250 filter T}Q~) is 
also shown in the figure. The transmittance of the uv-250 
filter T}Q~:) of the filter is 50"/, at A=250 nm and Oo/~ for A < 
200 mu. The cathode radiant sensitivity J~f(A) having the 
filter in place is considered by the product of I~) Q~) and 
T}Q~:) provided as shown below. 
Rf(~) R (~)¥T/ (~) 
R~Q~:) exhibits a spectral response complying with the light 
ranging from 200 to 320-nm brought about by the cutoff 
characteristics of the filter. The light intensity of the 
excirner lamp is measured by using and conculrently not 
by using the filter in an adequate place. Provided tbat 
radiation of the 172-nm VUV emitted fiom the lamp is 
The llluminating Engineering Institute of Japan 6 
J. Light & Vis. Env. Vol.31, No.1, 2007 
available, the light intensity measured by means of the 
filter in place will become remarkably smalLer than the 
light intensity measured without utilizing the filter. 
Although it may also be possible to detect VUV emission 
at 147 nm brought about by the Xe' resonance Ines by 
means of the phototube, the sensitivity at this wavelength 
almost corresponds to the 20th part of the one at 172 nm. 
By considerlng, in addition to the above, that the present 
experiment is perforned under the gas pressure at more 
than 400 Torr (53.3kPa), most of the resonance emissions 
are absorbed by the ground state atoms2G) 2D. Accordingly 
it can safely be said that the VUV light at 147 nm is 
believed to be negligible in this experirnent. 
3. Experirnental results and discussions 
3.1 Vlsible emission from exciner lamp 
Figure 3(a)-(d) shows the images of emissions of visible 
light obtained at the gas pressure of 760 Torr (101.3 kPa). 
These images were obtainable by using a single-reflex 
camera with exposure time of O.5 and F-number of 3.5. 
The upper side of the images corresponds to the top of the 
secondary part of the PT. The active emitting region, 
which is 30X15 mm, complies with the dischange space 
that is slightly larger than the area of the secondary part 
of the PT. The expeximents were conducted by allowing 
the primary voltage Vp to be increased in a range from 20 
to 45 V. Micro-discharges together with homogeneous 
emissions are observed in a style offilaments between the 
gaps. The DBD was first initiated at the primary voltage 
of 20 V. Secondly by increasing the primary voltage, the 
discharge regions were extended in a direction of the PT 
center (toward the bottom of the images).

760 Torr (i O1 .3 kPa), Gap length: 2 mm) 
At the primary voltage of 45 V, the DBD appears on the 
entire surface of the secondary part of the PT. From these 
results, it is understood that application of low voltages of 
15-45 V to the PT makes it possible to operate the excixner 
lamp in the discharge power region ranging from O.15 to 
0.55 W. Thus it becomes possible for the lanrp to work as a 
compact surfa~ light source. 
3.2 VUV detection using phototube and optical filter 
Figure 4 shows the light intensity detected by the 
7 
7 
phototube used as a iuction of discharge power. The open 
and solid circles indicate types of intensity ~6 and Sf 
measured by means of and without using the uv-250 
filter in pla~, respectively. 
Both types of light intensity were multiplied as the 
discharge power was increased, but the light intensity Sf 
measured by means of the ~ltcr in pla~ is 250 tixnes 
smaller than the light intensity S; measured without 
using the filter. By so doing, it is revealed that 99.6*/, of 
the radiation emitted by the excimer lamp is absorbed by 
the filter. It is explained from the above that the VLrv in 
the wavelength region ranging from 160 to 200 nm is 
radiated from the excimer lamp. Thus it is concluded that 
the detected \rUV can be regarded as 172 nm resulted 
from radiation from Xe2'. Considering that most of the 
radiation emitted from the lamp is absorbed by the filter, 
there remains no radiation between 200 and 320 nm. It is 
possible to infer from the results that light intensity 
detected by means of the filter correspond to those of the 
172-nm VUV

3.3 VUV characteristics of excilner lamp 
The VUV intensity as a function of the discharge power 
measured in the gas pressure region ranging from 400 to 
1000 Torr (53.3-133.3 kPa) is shown in Fig. 5(a). The gap 
length is maintained at 2 mm. Although the VUV 
intensity generally increases in proportion to heightening 
of the discharge power, the values come to be slightly 
saturated at higher discharge powers for each region of 
the gas pressure. Figure 5(b) shows types of VUV 
intensity plotted with respect to gas pressure for discharge 
powers ranging from O.2 to 0.6 W. The VUV intensity in 
this region is proportional to the gas pressure. These 
results suggest that in the region ranging from 400 to 
1000 Torr (53.3~133.3 kl)a), the concentration of the 
generated Xe2' excimers in the He-Xe DBD bringing about 
the number of photons at 172 nm is directly proportional 
to the gas density. High-gas pressure conditions enhance 
e~icient excimer formations because the 3-body reaction 
for the formation, Xe'+Xe+Xe ~> Xe2'+Xe rapidly arises 
prior to the decay process for the Xe' atoms. Such being

VUV intensities for dffferent gas pressures 
the case, it is imagined in this experiment that the 
mininum VUV intensity will be noti~d at the highest gas 
pressure of 1000 Torr (133.3 kPa). Figure 6(a)-(d) show 
types of VUV intensity complying with the discharge 
power obtained for gap lengths between 1.0 and 3.0 mm. 
Measurement was made several times with different 
types of pressure. As can be dedu~d from Fig. 5(b), the 
VUV intensity is proportional to the gas pressure. Thus it 
is preferred that the reduced VUV intensity I~,/p a.u.flbrr 
should be indicated, as the intensity is redu~d to I Torr 
(133.3 Pa) when obtained by dividing I~. by the gas 
pressure p. The redu~d VUV intensity I~./p, which is 
independent of the gas pressure for all gap lengths, 
increases linearly accompanied with increase of discharge 
power in the case of the gap length less than 2 mm. On a 
point of 3 mm in gap length, the redu~d intensity seems 
to be saturated at discharge powers of more than 0.4 W. 
Details of these results, which have not yet been made 
clear, might be explained quantitati'vely in the description 
shown below. 
The present experiment was conducted not only in the 
gas pressure region ranging from 400 to 1000 Torr (53.3 to 
133.3 kPa) but also at a gap length ranging from 0.1 to 0.3 
cm. Accordingly the pd product, which is in the right side 
of the Paschen minimum, can be estimated in a region 
ranging from 40 to 300 Torr ' cm. In this region, 
heightening of the pd product would lower ionization 
coefficient a:i/p, and excitation coefiicient a~ /p because of 
decrease in the reduced electric intensity L7p 
corresponding to the starting voltage of discharge. In 
this experixnent, increasing discharge power makes it 
possible to enhance the excitation and ionization, followed 
by the increase in light intensity as a result as depicted in 
Fig. 6. However taking into account the fact that the 
sustain voltage in the discharge gap is always constant 
during the DBD generation even if the applied voltage 
(primary voltage) of the PT increases, the reduced electric 
field intensity Llp (= V 7(pd )) Iikewise remains constant. 
For this reason, the increase in the discharge power is 
mainly due to the increase in the discharge curl'ent caused 
by development in the repetition of micro-discharge in the 
DBD. Thus it is hereby conclude d that the saturation 
characteristics of the light intensity in Fig. 6(d) is derived 
from the temperature increase based on the high current 
density. Furthermore a decrease in the excimer forrnation 
is resulted from the above.
